bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah Perry Senior and Junior, March 3, 1721

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchants, Micajah Perry, Senior, and his grandson of the same name, March 3, 1721, reporting the extensive deaths in his parish, and that he has lost many "fine Slaves" himself, and that he is suffering from the gout. He encloses a letter to his son John which, should John not be in England, they are to open and act upon its instructions.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah Perry Senior and Junior, March 3, 1721

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Mar. 3d. 1720/21
To
Messrs. Micajh. Perrys
Senr. & Junr.

div1.p:
I have little Material since my last The
Parish I live in these two last months hath bin visited with abundance of Mortalitys
I have lost a great many fine Slaves and have not bin Exempted
from the Distemper my self, and am now under a fitt of the Gout
that hath confin'd me to my Chair & bed these ten days, the cheif [sic]
occasion of this is to cover the Enclosed to my Son for Its better
Security. I am in no Expectation of having his company this
Year nor before the next Shipping. but if any fortuitous accid
ent Should happen to him or any Chymera come into his
head that Shall bring him away in the Ships that are now come
& he be out of England at the receipt hereof then I desire You to
open the Lettr. & to pursue the orders therein given wch. shall
be all at present from

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 85.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
